Jon Zelner `jzelner@umich.edu` [`epibayes.io`](https://epibayes.io)

![](../images/epid_logo.png){.absolute bottom=0 right=50 width="440" height="100"} ## Agenda - Defining the MAUP ðŸ˜± and the challenges it presents. - Implications of looking at the same phenomena over different scales. - Return of smoothing (if we have time...) ## What are some of the ways to define neighborhoods? Administrative neighborhoods : Census tracts, block groups, official neighborhoods Residential neighborhoods : Boundary definitions that reflect characteristic patterns of movement and exposure for people living in a given area Egocentric neighborhoods : Defined relative to the individual's location, may incorporate patterns of movement and exposure specific to them. # It came from the MAUP! {background-image="https://www.denofgeek.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/creature_from_the_black_lagoon_franchise_retrospective.jpg"} ## Scale Effects {.imgslide} ::: {.fragment} ![](../images/masters_pnas_scales.png) Aggregating up from low- to high-level spatial units results in biased estimates of measles outbreak risk.[@masters2020] ::: ## Zonation Effects {.imgslide} ::: {.fragment} ![](../images/ottawa_no2.png) Different neighborhood boundaries at the same scale result in different estimates of local N02 exposure. [@parenteau2011] ::: ## Administrative boundaries are very important for characterizing variation in policy-related outcomes ![Case rates of measles between Texarkana, TX and Texarkana, AR reflected state-level policy differences [@landrigan1972a]](../images/texarkana_measles.png) ## Environmental exposures like air pollution do not respect administrative boundaries ![Variation in N02 exposure in Ottawa, Ontario [@parenteau2011]](../images/ottawa_no2_continuous.png) ## What does any of this have to do with me? Take 5-10m to identify using this [miro board](https://miro.com/welcomeonboard/OEo2U0VDVkpiamhseVdMN243NTJHVkVpdk9iU0ZZSk1OeEJMQ09nell0NDE1aXpKUkMzRFBWbldMdXl0YWVmcXwzMDc0NDU3MzUwNDM2MzA5MTQx?invite_link_id=606920066591): - What are potential zonation effects for your project topic? - How about scale effects? ## Why should we be concerned about the tyrrany of neighborhoods? {.imgslide} :::{.fragment} ![](../images/petrovic_neighborhood_scales.png) Not all exposures happen at a single scale (From [@petrovic2020]) ::: ## A thought experiment about scales - Use individual-level data from Australian cities to examine correspondence between individual and neighborhood avg. wealth. - Build bespoke or egocentric neighborhoods around each location of increasing size. - Examine how the relationship between neighborhood average and individual incomes change with increasing size. - Not looking for the right scale, but instead for the implications of using each. ## What happens to variation in income as the scale of neighborhoods increases? {.imgslide} :::{.fragment} ![Variation within and between egocentric neighborhoods declines with increasing size [@petrovic2022]](../images/petrovic_amsterdam_income.png) ::: ## How does the relationship between individual and contextual income change over distance? {.imgslide} :::{.fragment} ![Share of low income people in neighborhood becomes a weaker predictor of individual income as scale increases [@petrovic2022]](../images/petrovic_amsterdam_2.png) ::: ## Petrovic et al. advocate a multi-scale approach - Higher-order structures constrain possibilities within lower-level ones. - The timescale of change at higher (e.g. city or region) levels is slower than at more-local levels. - What advantages do you see in taking a multi-scale approach to your problem? - What are the practical and theoretical challenges to doing so? ## Next Time {.imgslide} ![Examining segregation as a multi-scalar, multi-dimensional phenomenon](../images/lichter_high_macro_segregation.png) ## References
